terms.definition: SAGE is the next evolution after Business Intelligence (BI) — a unified platform designed to guide strategic decisions and execute actions across an organization. Unlike BI tools that focus on retrospective data visualization, SAGE actively understands business context, anticipates needs, and drives cross-departmental execution through AI-powered insights. It represents a shift from passive dashboards to proactive, decision-oriented intelligence.
Proprietary technology that automatically discovers and maps relationships between data points across different datasets, enabling seamless cross-platform analysis without manual configuration.
AI-powered system that allows users to ask questions about their data using plain English, automatically converting natural language into appropriate database queries.
Automated system that categorizes and tags data insights based on their type, importance, and business relevance, making it easier to organize and retrieve analytical findings.
Capability to analyze and correlate data from multiple sources simultaneously, providing comprehensive insights that span across different systems and databases.
Natural language processing approach that assigns confidence scores to interpretations and results, helping users understand the reliability of AI-generated insights.
Technologies, applications, and practices for collecting, integrating, analyzing, and presenting business information to support decision-making.
Isolated data repositories that are not easily accessible by other parts of an organization, creating barriers to comprehensive analysis and insights.
Approach to data analysis that brings together multiple data sources and analytical tools into a single, cohesive platform for comprehensive business insights.
Capability to analyze and respond to data as it arrives, providing immediate insights and enabling rapid decision-making based on current information.
Process of making data accessible to non-technical users through intuitive interfaces and tools, enabling broader organizational participation in data-driven decision making.
Programming language designed for managing and querying relational databases. Zamora.ai eliminates the need for users to know SQL through natural language interfaces.
Centralized repository that stores integrated data from multiple sources, optimized for analysis and reporting rather than transaction processing.
Process of extracting data from various sources, transforming it into a suitable format, and loading it into a target system like a data warehouse.
Set of protocols and tools that allow different software applications to communicate with each other, enabling data integration and system connectivity.
Visual interface that displays key metrics, KPIs, and data insights in an organized, easy-to-understand format for monitoring business performance.
Measurable values that demonstrate how effectively an organization is achieving key business objectives and goals.
Graphical representation of data and information using visual elements like charts, graphs, and maps to make complex data more accessible and understandable.
Type of artificial intelligence that enables systems to automatically learn and improve from experience without being explicitly programmed for every scenario.
Technology that enables machines to simulate human intelligence, including learning, reasoning, and problem-solving capabilities.
Process of combining data from different sources into a unified view, enabling comprehensive analysis across multiple systems and platforms.
Delivery of computing services including servers, storage, databases, and software over the internet, providing scalable and flexible IT resources.
Ability of a system to handle increased workload or expand to accommodate growth without compromising performance or requiring complete redesign.
Framework of policies, procedures, and standards that ensure data quality, security, and compliance throughout an organization.
Performance measure used to evaluate the efficiency and profitability of an investment, calculated as the ratio of net profit to investment cost.
Cloud-based software delivery model where applications are hosted by a service provider and made available to customers over the internet.
Storage repository that holds vast amounts of raw data in its native format until it's needed for analysis, supporting both structured and unstructured data.
Use of statistical algorithms and machine learning techniques to identify the likelihood of future outcomes based on historical data patterns.
Process of discovering patterns, correlations, and insights from large datasets using statistical and computational techniques.
Extremely large datasets that require specialized tools and techniques to capture, store, manage, and analyze due to their volume, velocity, and variety.
